newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Australia breeds fruit fly to cut pesticides.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Australia breeds fruit fly to cut pesticides.

text.p: New South Wales (NSW) will soon be breeding up to 20 million sterile fruit fly a week in an attempt to protect major fruit growing areas without the use of pesticides.
The sterile fruit fly will be bred at NSW Agriculture's Elizabeth Macarthur Agricultural Institute, Camden, in a new A$600,000 facility.

NSW Agriculture Minister Richard Amery said the fruit fly 'factory' was being funded by the Tri-State Fruit Fly Committee, comprising representatives of the NSW, Victorian, South Australian and federal governments and industry.
When the sterile fruit fly mate with wild fruit fly there will be no offspring, Amery said.
NSW Agriculture had been releasing sterile fruit fly in Wagga Wagga, NSW, since February with very positive results, he said.
